text.0: this light is come amid all lights the fairest born is the brilliant farextending brightness.
text.1: night sent away for savitars uprising hath yielded up a birthplace for the morning.
text.2: the fair the bright is come with her white offspring to her the dark one hath resigned her dwelling.
text.3: akin immortal following each other changing their colours both the heavens move onward.
text.4: common unending is the sisters pathway taught by the gods alternately they travel.
text.5: fairformed of different hues and yet oneminded night and dawn clash not neither do they travel.
text.6: bright leader of glad sounds our eyes behold her splendid in hue she hath unclosed the portals.
text.7: she stirring up the world hath shown us riches dawn hath awakened every living creature.
text.8: rich dawn she sets afoot the coiledup sleeper one for enjoyment one for wealth or worship.
text.9: those who saw little for extended vision all living creatures hath the dawn awakened.
text.10: one to high sway one to exalted glory one to pursue his gain and one his labour.
text.11: all to regard their different vocations all moving creatures hath the dawn awakened.
text.12: we see her there the child of heaven apparent the young maid flushing in her shining raiment.
text.13: thou sovran lady of all earthly treasure flush on us here auspicious dawn this morning.
text.14: she first of endless morns to come hereafter follows the path of morns that have departed.
text.15: dawn at her rising urges forth the living him who is dead she wakes not from his slumber.
text.16: as thou dawn hast caused agni to be kindled and with the suns eye hast revealed creation.
text.17: and hast awakened men to offer worship thou hast performed for gods a noble service.
text.18: how long a time and they shall be togetherdawns that have shone and dawns to shine hereafter.
text.19: she yearns for former dawns with eager longing and goes forth gladly shining with the others.
text.20: gone are the men who in the days before us looked on the rising of the earlier morning.
text.21: we we the living now behold her brightness and they come nigh who shall hereafter see her.
text.22: foechaser born of law the laws protectress joygiver waker of all pleasant voices.
text.23: auspicious bringing food for gods enjoyment shine on us here most bright o dawn this morning.
text.24: from days eternal hath dawn shone the goddess and shows this light today endowed with riches.
text.25: so will she shine on days to come immortal she moves on in her own strength undecaying.
text.26: in the skys borders hath she shone in splendour the goddess hath thrown off the veil of darkness.
text.27: awakening the world with purple horses on her wellharnessed chariot dawn approaches.
text.28: bringing all lifesustaining blessings with her showing herself she sends forth brilliant lustre.
text.29: last of the countless mornings that have vanished first of bright morns to come hath dawn arisen.
text.30: arise the breath the life again hath reached us darkness hath passed away and light approacheth.
text.31: she for the sun hath left a path to travel we have arrived where men prolong existence.
text.32: singing the praises of refulgent mornings with his hymns web the priest the poet rises.
text.33: shine then today rich maid on him who lauds thee shine down on us the gift of life and offspring.
text.34: dawns giving sons all heroes kine and horses shining upon the man who brings oblations.
text.35: these let the somapresser gain when ending his glad songs louder than the voice of vāyu.
text.36: mother of gods aditis form of glory ensign of sacrifice shine forth exalted.
text.37: rise up bestowing praise on our devotion allbounteous make us chief among the people.
text.38: whatever splendid wealth the dawns bring with them to bless the man who offers praise and worship.
text.39: even that may mitra varuṇa vouchsafe us and aditi and sindhu earth and heaven.
